query: What are the companies most exposed to flood risk?

nodes.label: precipitation extremes
nodes.description: Precipitation refers to any form of weather where substances fall from the sky, including rain, snow, sleet, or hail. Additionally, in chemistry, precipitation describes the process where a solid forms and settles out of a solution.

nodes.label: extreme weather
nodes.description: Extreme weather refers to events where a weather variable exceeds (or falls below) a threshold. Meaning it is significantly different from the average or usual weather pattern.

nodes.label: coastal flood
nodes.description: Coastal flooding often results from storm surges and high winds during high tides, with water levels rising due to low pressure and geographic factors.

nodes.label: flow-through dam
nodes.description: The flow-through dam is designed for the sole purpose of flood control, just one of the many possible functions of dams. An opening (spillway) is designed into the dam at about the same height as the river bed, so the structure is intended to let water flow through during normal times.

nodes.label: Riverine flood protection
nodes.description: A fluvial (riverine) flood is a rise, usually brief, in the water level of a stream or water body to a peak from which the water level recedes at a slower rate. Riverine flood protection refers to a set of measures and strategies designed to prevent or mitigate the impacts of flooding in areas adjacent to rivers.

nodes.label: risk
nodes.description: Risk is the potential for adverse consequences resulting from the dynamic interplay between (climate-related) hazards, exposure, and vulnerability of affected human or ecological systems.

nodes.label: sea overwash
nodes.description: Overwash is the flow of water and sediment over a coastal dune or beach crest during storm events. This process can cause significant coastal changes in the landscape of beaches and dunes.

nodes.label: extraterrestrial hazard
nodes.description: Extraterrestrial hazards are caused by asteroids, meteoroids, and comets as they pass near to the Earth, enter the Earth’s atmosphere, and/or strike the Earth, and by changes in interplanetary conditions that effect the Earth’s magnetosphere, ionosphere, and thermosphere.

nodes.label: Storm drains
nodes.description: A storm drain is part of the urban storm management system. It is an infrastructure designed to drain excess rain and ground water from impermeable surfaces and prevent or minimise flooding events.

nodes.label: elevated buildings
nodes.description: An elevated building, with regards to flooding, is a building that is raised on columns (or stilts) so that the floor level is higher than the potential level of the flood water.

nodes.label: Permeable parking lots
nodes.description: Permeable pavements and parking lots are often constructed in urban settings to facilitate storm water runoff and mitigate urban flooding and storm water overflow risks. The permeable surfaces provide greater water uptake. The water is infiltrated, and to an extent purified, before recharging the groundwater. The resulting retention decreases runoff rates and reduces pressures on urban storm water systems.

nodes.label: energy supply sector
nodes.description: The activities of industries involved in the production, distribution, and sale of energy, including electricity, gas, and renewables.

nodes.label: transportation sector
nodes.description: This sector involves activities to move goods and people, alongside the storage of products.

nodes.label: environmental management sector
nodes.description: This sector involves managing waste treatment, sanitation, pollution control and environmental cleanup.

nodes.label: healthcare sector
nodes.description: This sector provides medical services, manufactures medical equipment, and develops pharmaceuticals to maintain and improve health.

nodes.label: flooding waste
nodes.description: Damage caused by floods to the built environment.

nodes.label: drought
nodes.description: A drought is an extended period of unusually dry weather marked by a significant and sustained lack of precipitation, falling below a specific threshold over a large area for more than a month

nodes.label: hospitality sector
nodes.description: Activities that provide lodging, food, and entertainment services to guests, including hotels, restaurants, and resorts.

nodes.label: coastal community
nodes.description: A population living on the coast

nodes.label: water management sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the distribution, treatment, and conservation of water resources.

nodes.label: Flood hazard mapping
nodes.description: Flood hazard assessment and mapping is used to identify areas at risk of flooding, and consequently to improve flood risk management and disaster preparedness. Flood Hazard Mapping is a vital component for appropriate land use planning in flood-prone areas. It creates easily-read, rapidly-accessible charts and maps which facilitate the identification of areas at risk of flooding.

nodes.label: public emergency management
nodes.description: Process of coordinating and integrating all activities necessary to build, sustain, and improve the capability to mitigate against, prepare for, respond to, and recover from threatened or actual natural disasters, acts of terrorism, or other man-made disasters

nodes.label: trade sector
nodes.description: This sector involves the wholesale and retail selling of goods.

nodes.label: climate-risk early warning system
nodes.description: Early warning system for specific climate-risks, such as extreme weather events like storms or floods.

nodes.label: environmental risk
nodes.description: Environmental risk refers to adverse impacts on terrestrial, marine, and cryospheric systems from climate-related hazards, exposure, and vulnerability, and the risks related to air-pollution.

nodes.label: environmental consultancy services
nodes.description: The provision of environmental expertise and support services.

nodes.label: finance and insurance sector
nodes.description: Activities of businesses and institutions that provide financial services and products to individuals and organisations.

nodes.label: disaster waste impact
nodes.description: Disaster waste is waste generated by the impact of a disaster, both from the disaster itself and from poor waste management in the aftermath.

nodes.label: Flood forecasting systems
nodes.description: A flood warning system is a way of detecting threatening events in advance. This enables the public to be alerted in advance and can undertake appropriate responses to minimise the impact of the events.

nodes.label: agriculture sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve the cultivation of crops and raising of livestock for food, fibre, and other products essential for human life and industry.

nodes.label: geohazard
nodes.description: Geohazards are adverse geological phenomenon's that are capable of causing widespread damage or loss to property, life and the environment, such as earthquakes, volcano eruptions and tsunamis.

nodes.label: slow onset events
nodes.description: Slow onset events evolve gradually from incremental changes over many years or from increased frequency or intensity of recurring events. As defined in the Cancun Adaptation Framework (2010), slow onset events include risks and impacts from rising temperatures, desertification, biodiversity loss, land and forest degradation, glacial retreat, ocean acidification, sea level rise, and salinization.

nodes.label: flood
nodes.description: Floods are the inundation of normally dry land, resulting from a mix of hydrology, climate, and human factors, varying by type and region.

nodes.label: informal sector
nodes.description: Households employing domestic workers, for activities like cooking, cleaning and subsistence farming, for their own use.

nodes.label: Flood-proof sanitary latrines
nodes.description: Overflowing of sanitary latrines during flood events poses a serious health risk to communities in flood prone areas. The contaminated water may infiltrate surface or groundwater sources, causing pollution and disease. Improved construction design and planning of latrines can minimize these risks. Measures include elevating latrines or lining latrine pits to reduce waste infiltration and increase stability.

nodes.label: health impact
nodes.description: Climate change contributes to global disease and premature deaths. People are directly affected by changing weather patterns like temperature shifts, sea-level rise, and more frequent extreme events. Indirect impacts include changes in water, air, and food quality, as well as disruptions to ecosystems, agriculture, industry, settlements, and the economy. These effects are expected to increase.

nodes.label: societal impact
nodes.description: Climate change impacts our society by disrupting the natural, economic and social systems we depend on. Physical hazards and underlying vulnerabilities can lead to increased resource competition for food and water, which can heighten the risk of conflict.

nodes.label: exposed community
nodes.description: Communities that are significantly exposed to climate impacts due to their physical location

nodes.label: insurance activities
nodes.description: This area covers risk management through insurance products, including life, health, property, and casualty insurance

nodes.label: forestry sector
nodes.description: Activities that relate to the production of goods and services from forests.

nodes.label: chemical impact
nodes.description: Any substance with chemical properties that can cause physical harm to people or damage the environment, including ammonia, carbon monoxide, phosphine, chlorine, arsenic, cadmium, mercury, pesticides, dioxins, microplastics, benzene, asbestos, aflatoxins, fluoride, methanol, and toxins from marine sources.

nodes.label: fishing sector
nodes.description: Activities involving the catching, processing, and selling of fish for food, recreation, and industry.

nodes.label: technological impact
nodes.description: Climate change can have a range of impacts on technological system. Extreme weather events can cause infrastructure failures like power outages or damage to roads and bridges, as well as the impacts from waste following natural disasters. Human activities also cause technological impacts, such as the risks posed by oil spillage and leaks.

nodes.label: early warning system
nodes.description: An integrated single-hazard monitoring system that warns for impending extreme weather events and climate conditions, reducing the losses and damages and saving lives.

nodes.label: climate change governance
nodes.description: Development and implementation of strategies, regulations, and initiatives to mitigate, adapt, administrate risks, or deal with the transition from the impacts of climate change.

nodes.label: Adaptation technologies
nodes.description: Adaptation technologies are systems, tools, processes and innovations that facilitate the process of adjusting to and managing the current and future effects of climate change.

nodes.label: anthropogenic climate change
nodes.description: that human activity (e.g. burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and natural gas) is the dominant driver of the current changes to the climate and the environment

nodes.label: temperature extremes
nodes.description: Increases in the intensity, frequency, and duration of warm extremes and the decrease in those of cold extremes.

nodes.label: Runoff control structures
nodes.description: Runoff control structures are designed to capture runoff during peak flows, and can function as temporary storage sites. These structures are typically built with a discharge component to slowly release water into the nearby waterway to avoid it overflowing from the storage basin. It can be artificially built, for example by excavating a large area so that it is lower than the surrounding land.

nodes.label: storms
nodes.description: Storms are intense weather events with strong winds that can cause significant damage to infrastructure and ecosystems.
